title: Can I become a well-published author without a college education? - Quora

response.answer_text: Being an author is not related to your education, but rather to unique viewpoints and skill. Develop your own perspective on matters that other people are interested in and project it as your own loud and clear. Be definitive and prolific. No one cares if you write. They care if you have something new to say. Build a platform based on your new perspectives on existing subjects. Years later people will ask you where you learned it all and went to school. Start with some good outlines and research to make sure that you are inventing your own wheel. Then practice your pace of writing 3,000–5,000 words per day. Polish them as you go or revisiting them later. Throw away the first book that you finish or at least shelve it to revisit ten years later. Make your second book the first one that you reveal to the world. Always follow all submission instructions and find publishers who are producing work like your own and would be logically interested in what you are doing.

Back in the day it was rare for people to go on to college and many published writers among them Herman Melville - a well-published author to say the least- never went to college. Shakespeare is not known to have attended college. Even in these modern times there have been writers who didn't attend college. Ray Bradbury, Truman Capote, Agatha Christie, Doris Lessing (2007 Nobel Prize winner in literature) If we expand the list to those who dropped out of college and went to become well-published writers, the list gets longer.

Yes, absolutely. If you’re wanting to write a high-brow literary work of art like Dickens or Shakespeare, then people probably won’t give you due credit b/c you don’t have an MFA. But the rest of the world (that makes up the large majority of readers just wanting entertainment) - Heck yes, absolutely! You do not need a college education to write a book. What you do need: a good bookan editor to edit the pacing, grammar, plot holes, etc.a resilience to keep on going even if you get rejections or if you don’t feel like writingGood luck!

Those are two different and largely unconnected things. While most authors tend to have a college/university education, one doesn’t lead to the other. The author becomes successful by the stuff he/she writes about, not because of having or not having a college education. In short, it’s having a tellable story to write about that makes or breaks a writer. I have worked with quite a number of successful authors in my 35+ years in publishing, and some have nothing than junior secondary-school qualifications. I’ve worked with one author (successful too) who was a janitor, with no school-leaving certificates. You do what you can to write out your ‘story.’ You use your current educational level to maximise the possibilities and quality of writeup as best you can.

No one “needs” a college education to become a published writer. It would be literally throwing your money away to make that a prerequisite. Anne Rice never went to college (to my knowledge- I’ve read her statements about her background which emphasized her beginning as a waitress). I myself have no college degree and did not take writing -related college courses but every short story I’ve written has been published. I took one writing seminar which was just to get to meet some famous writers who gave us some evaluations and advice. It was fun - but not in any way essential or necessary. Writing is just a lot of work but it’s also just goddam fun and an enjoyable challenge if you’re up to it. The other side of this same coin: some of the most worthless, snobbish people I know “pretend” to be writers and intellectuals just because they have college degrees. The idea that you need a college education to “qualify” is pure bull shit educational propaganda.

Of course you can! You have to educate yourself in the process of writing a good story, of course, but anyone can do that. Many people succeed at many things without a college education. Read books: The Writer’s Journey by Christopher Vogler, Techniques of the Selling Writer by Dwight Swain, Writing Dialogue by Charles Chiarella are a good start. And/or take classes at writer’s conferences, at your local community college… and read, read, read books in the genre you want to write in!
